Stage

Description

Key Features

I - Preseptal cellulitis

Infection confined to the eyelid

II - Orbital cellulitis

Infection spreads to the orbit

III - Subperiosteal abscess

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent chest pain and difficulty swallowing for the past few months. The chest pain is often severe and mimics angina but is not related to exertion. His symptoms often occur at night. Barium swallow reveals a typical finding given below. Which of the following disorders is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Uncoordinated, simultaneous contractions of the esophagus with normal LES function.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia (solids and liquids)
  • Severe chest pain
  • Less common regurgitation
  • Globus sensation

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry: Multiple simultaneous non-peristaltic contractions with an amplitude of > 30 mmHg; normal LES pressure and relaxation.
 

Barium Swallow (Esophagram): "Corkscrew" or "Rosary bead" appearance.

(Option A)
 

Endoscopy: Generally normal mucosa; rule out structural abnormalities.

Management

Non-Pharmacological: Dietary Modifications (smaller, frequent meals)
 

Pharmacological:

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
  • Nitrates (e.g., isosorbide dinitrate)
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection
 

Surgical:

  • Esophageal Myotomy (rare)
  • Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)
 

Endoscopic: Dilation (less effective)

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with early breast development and pubic hair growth. Which among the following investigations can differentiate between central and peripheral causes of precocious puberty?
Which of the following correctly describes the sequence of events during gastrulation in the third week of gestation?

options.label: A
options.text: Epiblast cells form the primitive streak, leading to the formation of the three germ layers.

options.label: B
options.text: The primitive streak forms at the cephalic end, initiating neural tube, gut, and cardiovascular development.

options.label: C
options.text: The prechordal plate forms after the notochord, and epiblast cells migrate to create the three germ layers.

options.label: D
options.text: The Endoderm forms from mesodermal cells, with ectoderm and mesoderm forming later.

questions.correct_answer: A. Epiblast cells form the primitive streak, leading to the formation of the three germ layers.
questions.explanation:
Start of Process
  • Formation of the primitive streak on the surface of the epiblast.

Primitive Streak
  • Initially indistinct, it becomes a narrow groove with bulging regions by days 15-16.

Primitive Node
  • Located at the cephalic end of the streak, a slightly raised area surrounding a small pit.

Cell Migration
  • Epiblast cells migrate toward the primitive streak and undergo invagination.

Invagination
  • Cells transform into flask-shaped forms, detach from the epiblast, and move beneath it.

Regulation
  • Fibroblast growth factor 8 (FGF8) regulates cell movement and mesoderm formation.
  • FGF8 decreases E-cadherin levels, which helps in migration

Cell Spread
  • Invaginated cells replace the hypoblast and spread laterally and cranially.

Contact with Extraembryonic Mesoderm
  • Cells establish contact with the extraembryonic mesoderm covering the yolk sac and amnion.

Prechordal Plate
  • Forms between the notochord tip and the oropharyngeal membrane.
  • Important for forebrain induction.

Oropharyngeal Membrane
  • Composed of tightly joined ectoderm and endoderm cells.
  • Will become the future oral cavity opening.

Formation of Germ Layers
  • Endoderm: Displaces the hypoblast.
  • Mesoderm: Forms between the epiblast and endoderm.
  • Ectoderm: Develops from the Remains of the epiblast.

Outcome
  • The epiblast gives rise to all embryonic tissues and organs through the process of gastrulation.

questions.text: Which stimulation pattern is specifically designed to assess deep neuromuscular blockade?
questions.explanation:
Stimulation Pattern

Mechanism

Interpretation

Clinical Implication and Limitation

Single-Twitch Stimulation

(Option B)

Single electrical stimulus applied at a frequency of 0.1 Hz to 1 Hz.

Requires comparison to pre-NMBA administration value.

Muscle response to the stimulus reflects neuromuscular block onset; changes in twitch height help assess blockade.

Used to evaluate onset of neuromuscular block.

Limited utility as a standalone test.

Train-of-Four (TOF) Stimulation

(Option A)

Four supramaximal stimuli delivered at 0.5-second intervals (2 Hz).

Fade between responses indicates degree of block.

TOF count assesses onset.

TOF ratio measures recovery.

Fade suggests nondepolarizing block.

Most common pattern for intraoperative monitoring.

Cannot measure deep block or phase I block.

Double-Burst Stimulation (DBS)

(Option D)

Two bursts of 50-Hz stimulation with a 750-ms interval.

Fade between the two bursts indicates block.

Fade between bursts correlates with TOF ratio.

DBS is more sensitive for detecting fade.

Better tactile detection of residual block than TOF but cannot reliably assess recovery at higher TOF ratios.

Tetanic Stimulation

High-frequency stimulation (50-100 Hz for 5 seconds) causing sustained muscle contraction.

Fade indicates nondepolarizing block; sustained response suggests normal transmission or depolarizing block.

Painful and limited use in practice.

May cause lasting muscle antagonism, affecting recovery assessment.

Post Tetanic Count (PTC) Stimulation

(Option C)

Tetanic stimulation (50 Hz for 5 seconds) followed by single twitches at 1 Hz after 3 seconds.

Counts discernible twitches after tetanic stimulation; assesses deep block not detectable by TOF.

Used for monitoring deep neuromuscular blockade.

Requires 6-minute intervals, limiting continuous use.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female from Africa presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pallor, and generalised lymphadenopathy. Given her clinical features, there is a high suspicion of kala-azar. Which laboratory tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? rk39 serological test Bone marrow aspirate Splenic aspirate Liver biopsy
questions.explanation:
Microscopy

Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of kala-azar / VL

 

Materials collected:

Peripheral blood smear: Peripheral blood contains the amastigotes present inside circulating monocytes. It is best to examine buffy coat smear, Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night.

 

Blood smear test showing macrophages with amastigotes and extracellular Leishmania parasites (white arrows)

 

Bone marrow aspirate: Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Bone marrow samples can also be obtained by puncturing the Iliac crest.

 

Bone marrow aspirate showed Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies) in macrophages characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Fig. A and B).

Splenic aspirate (most sensitive): Splenic aspirates are richer in parasites and, therefore, are more valuable for diagnosis. Splenic aspiration is contraindicated in patients with prolonged prothrombin time or if platelet count is less than 40,000/mm³

Lymph node aspirate: It is not useful in the diagnosis of Indian kala-azar

Culture

Media: NNN (Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle).

Serodiagnosis
  1. Detection of antigen: ELISA and PCR
  2. Detection of antibody:
    • rk39 test: A specific rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) method for antibodies using a recombinant leishmanial antigen rk 39. The sensitivity of the test is 98% and specificity is 90%.
    • Complement fixation test
    • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT)
    • Counter immunoelectrophoresis (CIEP)
    • ELISA and DOT-ELISA
    • Direct agglutination test (DAT)

Non-specific serum tests
  1. Napier aldehyde test
  2. Chopra's antimony test

Skin test

  • Leishmanin skin test- Montenegro test: Delayed hypersensitivity test.
  • Positive result is indicated by induration and erythema of 5 mm or more after 48-72 hours.
  • Positive result indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasites. In active kala-azar, this test is negative and becomes positive usually 6-8 weeks after cure from the disease.

Image obtained after 48 hours after injection

Complete blood count
  • It shows normocytic normochromic anemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Leukocyte count reveals leukopenia.
  • The ratio of leukocyte to erythrocyte is greatly altered and may be about 1:200 to 1:100 (normal 1:750).
  • The serum shows hypergammaglobulinemia and a reversal of the albumin: globulin (A: G) ratio.
  • Liver function tests show mild elevations of liver enzymes.
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated.

questions.text: A 16-month-old child is visiting the clinic for a routine check-up. The child's parents enquire about starting the varicella vaccination series. The child is healthy and has no known allergies or medical conditions. Which of the following vaccination schedules is most appropriate for this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 23 months later.

options.label: B
options.text: Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 3-6 months later.

options.label: C
options.text: Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 2 weeks later.

options.label: D
options.text: Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 1 month later.

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 3-6 months later.
questions.explanation:
VARICELLA VACCINE

About Vaccine
  • Live-attenuated vaccine
  • Oka strain

Dose, Route & Site
  • 0.5 mL, Subcutaneously
  • Anterolateral thigh or upper arm

National Program

Not included

IAP 2021
  • All children, especially high-risk categories; those exposed to varicella, and exposed unvaccinated adolescents/adults.
  • The first dose is taken at 15-18 months (minimum age 12 months).
  • Second dose 3-6 months later.

Catch Up

Administer two doses ≥3 months apart (≥4 weeks apart if over 13 years old) for those without proof of immunity.

Post-exposure prophylaxis

When administered for PEP within 72 hours of contact, a single dose of the vaccine offers only about 70% protective efficacy.

Adverse Reactions
  • Fever, rash, local pain or redness.
  • Mild rash after 2-3 weeks (5%).

C/I
  • The IAP advises against administering the MMR-V vaccine to children under 2 years old.
  • Anaphylaxis after the previous dose
  • Immunodeficiency
  • Active leukaemia or lymphoma
  • During immunosuppressive therapy

Precautions
  • Moderate to severe illness
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Recent receipt of blood products or immunoglobulins
  • Therapy with aspirin

Storage
  • Freeze-dried, lyophilized; Store at 2-8°C; Protect from light.
  • Use within 30 minutes of reconstitution.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with sudden, massive hematemesis. An upper endoscopy identifies a small mucosal defect surrounded by normal gastric mucosa. Angiography reveals a large, tortuous artery in the left gastric artery distribution. What is the underlying pathophysiological mechanism of bleeding in Dieulafoy’s lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: Erosion of the mucosa due to excessive acid secretion

options.label: B
options.text: Rupture of varices caused by portal hypertension

options.label: C
options.text: Erosion of mucosa due to pulsations from a large submucosal artery

options.label: D
options.text: Ulceration of the gastric mucosa due to chronic use of NSAIDs

questions.correct_answer: C. Erosion of mucosa due to pulsations from a large submucosal artery
questions.explanation:
Dieulafoy’s lesion
  • Dieulafoy's lesion is characterized by an abnormally large, tortuous artery that runs through the submucosa of the stomach without a primary ulcer.
  • Artery measures 1-3 mm and is typically found near the gastroesophageal junction along the lesser curvature.
  • The lesion develops as the pulsations of the large submucosal artery erode the superficial mucosa. (Option C)
  • The mucosal defect is usually small, measuring 2-5 mm, and is surrounded by normal-appearing gastric mucosa. Once the artery is exposed to gastric contents, further erosion and bleeding occur.

Demographics

More common in men (2:1 ratio) and is associated with cardiovascular disease, chronic kidney disease, and diabetes.

Clinical Presentation

Sudden onset of massive, painless hematemesis (vomiting blood).

Diagnosis

Endoscopy: Primary tool, identifies lesion in 80% of cases; repeat may be needed.

Angiography: Used if endoscopy is inconclusive; shows tortuous artery and potential contrast extravasation.

Treatment

Endoscopic Therapy:

  • Bipolar electrocoagulation,
  • Heater probe thermocoagulation,
  • Injection sclerotherapy,
  • Endoscopic hemoclipping.

Angiographic Embolization:

  • Used when endoscopy fails.

Surgery:

  • Wedge resection of the stomach if other methods fail; intraoperative endoscopy or tattooing aids in locating the lesion.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy presents with failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intermittent episodes of vomiting and lethargy. The episodes coincide with the introduction of solid foods. Blood tests reveal elevated ammonia levels and high levels of ornithine in blood. Urine analysis shows increased excretion of homocitrulline. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Hyperornithinemia-Hyperammonemia-Homocitrullinuria Syndrome

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Defective Gene

ORC1

Defective Protein

Mitochondrial Ornithine Transporter: This transporter moves ornithine into the mitochondria and citrulline out of the mitochondria.

Mechanism
  • Prevents ornithine from entering the mitochondria, which is necessary for the urea cycle.
  • The buildup of ammonia in the blood (hyperammonemia).
  • Ornithine also accumulates in the cytoplasm (hyperornithinemia).
  • Carbamoyl phosphate reacts with lysine to form homocitrulline.

Symptoms
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Developmental delay.
  • Intermittent episodes of vomiting and lethargy (triggered by protein intake).
  • Seizures.
  • Intellectual disability.

Diagnosis
  • Elevated blood ammonia
  • Elevated blood ornithine
  • Elevated urinary homocitrulline.

Treatment
  • Low-protein diet
  • Nitrogen scavenger medications
  • Liver transplant in severe cases.

questions.text: Match the following phases of translation (Column A) with the events involved (Column B). Column A Column B 1. Elongation a. RF1 binds with RF3 and GTP 2. Initiation b. Binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosome's A site 3. Termination c. Methionine tRNA scans mRNA for AUG codon
questions.explanation:
Phases of translation

Key events

Initiation
  • Dissociation of 80s ribosome into 60s and 40s, and stabilized by various initiation factors.
  • Formation of the 43S Preinitiation Complex: The 40S ribosomal subunit, in association with initiation factors, binds to the initiator tRNA (carrying methionine in eukaryotes or formyl-methionine in prokaryotes)forming the 43S preinitiation complex.
  • Formation of 48S initiation complex: The 43S complex binds to the 5' end of the mRNA, and scans for start codon which upon recognition, the 48S initiation complex is formed.
  • Formation of the 80S Initiation Complex: Binding of the 60S ribosomal subunit to the 48S initiation. The met-tRNA on the P site of the ribosome is ready for the elongation cycle.

Elongation
  • Binding of Aminoacyl-tRNA to the A Site
  • Peptide Bond Formation
  • Elongation factor 2 (EF2) binds to and displaces the peptidyl tRNA from the A site to the P site

Termination
  • Ribosome reaches the terminator codon sequence (UAA, UAG or UGA)
  • Releasing factor(RF1), (RF3) and GTP complex promotes hydrolysis releasing the protein and the tRNA from the P site.

questions.text: Match the following. i) X-linked Agammaglobulinemia a) WAS ii) Job syndrome b) LYST iii) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome c) STAT3 iv) Ataxia Telangiectasia d) BTK v) Chediak-Higashi syndrome e) ATM

questions.explanation:

BTK

Job syndrome (Hyper IgE syndrome)

STAT3

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

WAS

Ataxia Telangiectasia

ATM

Chediak-Higashi syndrome

LYST

Defects in Leukocyte Function

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in the β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in fucosyl transferase required for the synthesis of sialylated oligosaccharide (receptor for selectins)

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 3

LAD-III is caused by mutations in the FERMT3 gene, which encodes kindlin-3, a cytoskeletal protein. These mutations disrupt the signalling of integrins on platelets and leukocytes, which impairs cellular adhesion

Chédiak-Higashi syndrome

Autosomal recessive, decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein (LYST) involved in lysosomal membrane traffic. Defective phagolysosome formation.

Chronic granulomatous disease

Decreased oxidative burst

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

Defects in the Complement System

C2, C4 deficiency

Defective classical pathway activation results in reduced resistance to infection and reduced clearance of immune complexes

C3 deficiency

Defects in all complement functions

Deficiency of complement regulatory proteins

Excessive complement activation; clinical syndromes include angioedema (C1 inhibitor deficiency), paroxysmal hemoglobinuria (CD55/59 deficiency), others

SCID
  • X-linked (most common): mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors
  • Autosomal recessive: ADA enzyme deficiency

X-Linked Agammaglobulinemia (Bruton Agammaglobulinemia)
  • BTK gene mutation
  • X-linked recessive

DiGeorge Syndrome (Thymic Hypoplasia)
  • CATCH22 (mnemonic) - Cardiac defects, Abnormal facies, Thymic hypoplasia, Cleft palate, Hypocalcemia (tetany) resulting from lack of parathyroids, 22q11 microdeletion

Hyper IgM syndrome
  • Defective CD40L on helper T cells → class switching defect
  • X-linked recessive

Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Cause unknown
  • Defects in B and T cells
  • Defective B cell: BAFF gene defect
  • Defective T cell: ICOS gene defect
  • Diagnosed in late childhood or adulthood

Isolated IgA Deficiency
  • Caused by impaired differentiation of naïve B lymphocytes to IgA-producing plasma cells

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
  • Mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP)

Ataxia Telangiectasia
  • Autosomal recessive
  • ATM gene mutation located on chromosome 11

questions.explanation:
Type of Ectropion

Description

Causes

Clinical Features

Treatment

Involutional Ectropion
  • Most common; age-related
  • Horizontal laxity
  • Canthal tendon laxity
  • Epiphora
  • Tarsal thinning
  • Lagophthalmos
  • Medial conjunctivoplasty for mild cases.
  • Horizontal lid shortening for moderate cases.
  • Byron Smith's modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation for severe cases.
  • Lateral tarsal strip technique for generalized ectropion.

Cicatricial Ectropion
  • Scarring of anterior lamella
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Scarring conditions (e.g., blepharitis)
  • Scarring
  • Skin fibrosis
  • Mild cases: V-Y operation.
  • Mild to moderate cases: Z-plasty (Elschnig's operation).
  • Severe cases: Excision of scar tissue and full-thickness skin grafting.

Paralytic Ectropion
  • Facial nerve palsy (Bell’s)
  • Bell’s palsy
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Exposure keratopathy
  • Temporary measures: Topical lubricants, eyelid taping, suture tarsorrhaphy.
  • Permanent measures (if needed): Horizontal lid tightening with/without middle lamellar buttress, palpebral sling operation.

Mechanical Ectropion
  • Mass or lesion pushing eyelid
  • Tumors
  • Conjunctival growths
  • Eyelid displacement
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Treat the underlying mechanical causes.

Congenital Ectropion
  • Present at birth

  • Down syndrome

  • Mild cases may not require treatment.

questions.text: Match the following: 1. Durham’s rule a. A person is not guilty because of insanity if they were unaware of the nature, quality, and consequences of their acts or could not realise they were wrong. 2. Curren’s rule b. An accused is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act is the product of mental disease or defect. 3. McNaughten’s rule c. An accused is not criminally responsible if, at the time of the act, they couldn’t regulate their conduct due to mental disease or defect.
questions.explanation:
Durham’s rule
  • An accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of a mental disease or mental defect.
  • Later, this rule was discarded in the USA.

Curren’s rule

An accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.

McNaughten’s rule

(Section 84, IPC,

Section 22, BNS)
  • A person is not criminally responsible if, due to a mental disease, they were unaware of the nature and consequences of their actions or unable to recognise that the act was wrong.
  • It has the following requirements:
    • There must be evidence of a mental disorder.
    • The mental disorder must be present at the time of the crime.
    • The disorder must impair the individual's ability to understand the wrongfulness or illegality of the act.

Section 85 IPC

(Section 23 BNS)
  • A person who is intoxicated may not be criminally responsible if they were so impaired at the time of the act that they could not understand the nature of their actions or recognize that their actions were wrong or illegal.
  • This applies only if the intoxication was caused against their will or without their knowledge.

Section 86 IPC

(Section 24 BNS)
  • A voluntarily intoxicated person is still considered criminally responsible if they had the intention or knowledge to commit a crime, despite their intoxication.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a content of the broad ligament?
questions.explanation:
Broad Ligament

Definition

Two winglike structures extending from the lateral uterine margins to the pelvic sidewalls, each formed by a double layer of peritoneum

Function

The broad ligament helps stabilize the uterus's position within the pelvic cavity.

Contents
  • Fallopian tube - Upper portion: The peritoneum that folds over the fallopian tube is the mesosalpinx.
  • Round ligament - Anteriorly: The peritoneum surrounding the round ligament is called the mesoteres. (Option A)
  • Ovarian ligament - Posterior fold: The peritoneum that encompasses the ovarian ligament is known as the mesovarium.
  • Vestigial structures of Wolffian body - Epoophoron and paroophoron.
  • Vestigial structure of Wolffian duct - Gartner's duct.
  • Ureter. (Option B)
  • Uterine vessels.
  • Pelvic nerves.
  • Parametrial lymph node.
  • Pelvic cellular tissue condensed to form Mackenrodt 's ligament.
  • lnfundibulopelvic ligament (suspensory ligament of the ovary) - Outer border of the broad ligament. (Option C)

Blood Supply
  • Uterine artery, courses through the base of the broad ligament and supplies the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.
  • Ovarian artery, enters the broad ligament through the infundibulopelvic ligament and supplies the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

Which of the following is the comprehensive program the Ministry of Women and Child Development launched to combat trafficking?
questions.explanation:
The Ujjawala scheme

The Ujjawala scheme, launched in India on December 4, 2007, by the Ministry of Women and Child Development, is a comprehensive program to combat trafficking. The scheme is primarily implemented through NGOs.

Objectives/Goals

Strategies to Achieve Goals

Prevention

  • Formation of community vigilance and adolescent groups, awareness creation
  • preparation of IEC (Information, Education, Communication) material, organization of workshops.

Rescue
  • Safe withdrawal of victims from the place of exploitation.

Rehabilitation
  • Providing safe shelter, basic amenities, medical care, legal aid, vocational training, and employment opportunities to victims.

Reintegration
  • Supporting victims in their reintegration into society.

Repatriation

  • Providing support to cross-border victims for their safe return to their home countries.

Position the head, provide oxygen, and monitor vital signs.

↓

Establish vascular access and check glucose levels.

↓

Administer benzodiazepines (preferably lorazepam IV).

↓

If seizures persist after 2 doses of benzodiazepines.

↓

Administer antiepileptic drugs (Fosphenytoin, Phenytoin, Levetiracetam, Valproic acid).

↓

If refractory status epilepticus suspected

↓

Initiate continuous infusion of Midazolam, Pentobarbital, Thiopental, or Propofol.

questions.text: A 35-year-old carpenter presents with pain and weakness in his right forearm after repetitive hammering. On examination, you note tenderness over the medial epicondyle and weakness in wrist flexion. There is no sensory loss. Based on these findings, which muscle is not likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Origin
  • Humeral head- Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon)
  • Ulnar head - Coronoid process of the ulna

Insertion

Lateral surface of the midshaft of the radius.

Action

Pronates the forearm and weak flexor of elbow.

Nerve Supply

Median nerve (C6, C7).

Origin

Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon).

Insertion

Base of the second and third metacarpal bones.

Action

Flexes and abducts the wrist (radial deviation).

Nerve Supply

Median nerve (C6, C7).

Origin

Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon).

Insertion

Flexor retinaculum and palmar aponeurosis.

Action

Flexion of hand at wrist makes palmar aponeurosis tense.

Nerve Supply

Median nerve (C7, C8).

Origin
  • Humeral head- Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon)
  • Ulnar head- Olecranon and posterior border of the ulna.

Insertion

Pisiform, hook of hamate, and base of the fifth metacarpal.

Action

Flexes and adducts the wrist

Nerve Supply

Ulnar nerve (C7, C8).

Origin
  • Humeroulnar head- Medial epicondyle of the humerus and coronoid process of the ulna
  • Radial head- Oblique line of the radius

Insertion

Middle phalanges of the 2nd to 5th digits.

Action

Flexion of middle and proximal phalanges of digits.

Nerve Supply

Median nerve (C7, C8, T1)

On examination, Angiotensin-converting enzyme levels were elevated. Lymph node biopsy showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener’s Granulomatosis)

(Option C)
  • Autoimmune necrotizing vasculitis.
  • Granulomas in respiratory tracts and kidneys.
  • Facial nerve paralysis with Sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Diagnosis: Elevated c-ANCA.
  • Treatment: Cyclophosphamide + steroids.

Lyme Disease

(Option B)
  • Cause: Borrelia burgdorferi, Vector: Hard tick.

                      Fig: Erythema migrans
  • Diagnosis: Serologic testing.
  • Treatment: Doxycycline or amoxicillin, if contra-indicated - Azithromycin.

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

Melkersson–Rosenthal Syndrome

(Option A)

A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and bone pain for the past several months. She has a history of hypothyroidism and is currently taking levothyroxine. She lives in North India and avoids dairy products. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness over her shins. Laboratory tests reveal: Serum calcium 8.2 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL) Serum phosphorus 2.0 mg/dL (normal range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL) Parathyroid hormone (PTH) Elevated Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Biochemical Feature

Explanation

Hypocalcemia

Due to decreased calcium absorption in the intestine.

Hypophosphatemia

Due to decreased phosphate absorption in the intestine and decreased reabsorption of phosphate in the kidneys.

Secondary Hyperparathyroidism

In response to low calcium levels, the parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases, which increases calcium reabsorption from bone and the kidneys.

Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)

Due to Increased bone turnover as a result of increased PTH.

25-hydroxy cholecalciferol

Decreased.

Muscle

Origin

Insertion

Actions

  • Middle fibers: Medial margin of the acromion and upper lip of the spine of the scapula

questions.text: What is the major concern associated with bupivacaine toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Classification
  • Bupivacaine is an amide-type local anesthetic

Mechanism of Action

  • It works by blocking sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing the propagation of nerve impulses, which results in local anesthesia.

Clinical Uses

  • Commonly used for spinal, epidural, and peripheral nerve blocks.
  • Widely used in labor and delivery for epidural anesthesia and in long-duration surgeries.

Duration of Action
  • Longer duration of action compared to other local anesthetics like lidocaine. It can provide anesthesia for several hours, making it ideal for prolonged procedures.

Onset of Action
  • Has a slower onset (10-15 minutes) compared to faster-acting anesthetics like lidocaine.

Cardiotoxicity
  • Major concern with bupivacaine is its potential for cardiotoxicity, especially at higher doses or when inadvertently injected intravenously, leading to severe arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

Metabolism
  • Metabolized primarily in the liver by cytochrome P450 enzymes and excreted by the kidneys.

Enantiomers
  • The S-enantiomer of bupivacaine, known as levobupivacaine, is associated with reduced cardiotoxicity and is often used as a safer alternative.

Lipid Solubility & Protein Binding

  • Bupivacaine has high lipid solubility and high protein binding, which contributes to its prolonged duration of action.

Contraindications
  • Should be avoided in patients with severe cardiac arrhythmias, and caution should be used in patients with liver disease due to its hepatic metabolism.

Common Side Effects
  • In addition to cardiotoxicity, other potential side effects include CNS toxicity, such as dizziness, seizures, and lightheadedness, especially with accidental intravascular injection.

Toxicity
  • Direct intravenous injection or rapid vascular uptake of the drug is the most common reason for bupivacaine toxicity, which has an upper limit of 2.5 to 3.5 mg/kg upper limit of dosing.
  • Treatment for toxicity: 20% intralipid solution.

questions.text: In the Complement Fixation Test (CFT), what indicates a positive result?

options.label: A
options.text: Lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs)

options.label: B
options.text: Formation of an immune complex between antigen and antibody

options.label: C
options.text: No lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs)

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of active complement in the serum

questions.correct_answer: C. No lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs)
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

Step 1: Complement Fixation

1. Heat patient serum to inactivate native complement.

2. Add known antigen or antibody and complement.

3. Immune complex fixes the complement if a specific antigen or antibody is present.

Step 2: Indicator Stage

1. Add sensitised SRBCs (coated with amboceptor) to the mixture.

2. Positive CFT: Complement fixed, no SRBC lysis.

3. Negative CFT: Free complement lyses SRBCs.

Test Type

Description

Immune Adherence

Bacteria aggregate and adhere to cells (e.g., erythrocytes) in the presence of complement and specific antibodies.

Immobilisation Test

Antibodies inhibit bacterial motility with complement (e.g., Treponema pallidum immobilisation test).

Cytolytic/Cytocidal Tests

Bacteria are lysed or killed when mixed with specific antibodies and complement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with opioid use disorder presents with severe muscle aches, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, restlessness, and chills after stopping heroin "cold turkey." He has piloerection, dilated pupils, tachycardia, and mild hypertension. He refuses opioid for managing the withdrawals. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacological treatment for his opioid withdrawal symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Opioid Withdrawal

Detoxification

Maintenance
  • Opioid Agents
  • Methadone: Opioid Agonist.
  • Buprenorphine:Partial Opioid Agonist.

Opioid Substitution Therapy (OST):

  • Methadone: Full opioid agonist
    • Improves treatment retention and reduces criminal behavior.
    • 80–120 mg/day.
    • Side effects: constipation, sweating, sexual dysfunction.
  • Buprenorphine:
    • Partial opioid agonist with a ceiling effect (limits overdose risk).
    • Combined with naloxone to prevent abuse.
    • Taken sublingually (tablet/film).
    • Side effects: constipation, nausea, drowsiness.
 
  • Opioid Antagonists (Naloxone, Naltrexone):
    • Naloxone: Reverses opioid overdose (emergency use).
    • Naltrexone: Blocks opioid effects to prevent euphoria, reduces opioid cravings. Available in oral and long-acting injectable forms.
    • Does not cause dependence or withdrawal but requires patient adherence.

Opioid addicted patient but unwilling to be treated with opioids: Symptomatic agents

  • Clonidine
    • Alpha-2 Adrenergic Agonist.
    • Reduces autonomic withdrawal symptoms- Sweating, Restlessness, Tremor or Rhinorrhea.
  • Anxiety: Benzodiazepines
  • Insomnia: Zolpidem
  • Musculoskeletal Pain: NSAIDs (Ibuprofen)
  • GI Symptoms: Antiemetic Diarrhea (Loperamide)

Pregnant Women with Opioid Use Disorder:

  • Illicit opioid use during pregnancy increases risks for both mother and baby
  • Methadone or buprenorphine maintenance reduces risks, though neonatal opioid withdrawal may still occur.
  • Associated risks- Neonatal infections (HIV), premature labor, low birth weight, and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

Psychotherapy Modalities/ Non- Pharmacological Treatment:

  • Effective treatments: Individual therapy, CBT, family therapy, support groups (NA), and social skills training.
  • Social skills training is key for patients with poor social skills.
  • Residential programs for people with substance use disorders.
  • Education on HIV transmission and safe sex is essential.
  • Needle-exchange programs, where available, help reduce unsafe needle sharing and associated infections.
  • Narcotics Anonymous (NA): A 12-step self-help group for abstinent drug addicts.

The patient has a temperature of 102 degrees, 128 beats per minute heart rate, and elevated white blood cell count. Which diagnostic test is most appropriate for confirming in this patient?

Simple Obstruction

Strangulating Obstruction

Definition

Mechanical obstruction with intact blood supply.

Mechanical obstruction with compromised blood supply.

Pain

Crampy, colicky pain.

Constant, steady pain.

Systemic Symptoms

Typically absent or mild.

Fever, tachycardia, and elevated white blood cell count.

Diagnostic Tests

Abdominal X-ray (initial assessment).

Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT).

Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT) for detailed evaluation.

Additional Features

Usually no systemic signs of infection or inflammation.

Systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever) and inflammation.

Management

Can be managed with conservative treatment or surgery if necessary.

Requires urgent surgical intervention to address ischemia and restore blood flow.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a history of two miscarriages, both occurring in the first trimester. Genetic testing of the products of conception shows chromosomal anomalies. What is the most common chromosomal abnormality to cause abortions among the following?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Isolated Abortion

Causes of Recurrent Abortion

Chromosomal abnormalities are the most common causes of early miscarriages.

  • Autosomal trisomy is the most common cause of cytogenetic abnormality which accounts for 50% of cases.
  • The most common trisomy is Trisomy 16. (Option C) (30%)
  • Polyploidy is observed in 22% of cases.
  • Monosomy X (20%) and structural chromosomal rearrangements (2-4%) are also observed.
 

Infections:

  • Viral: Rubella, cytomegalovirus, variola, vaccinia or HIV.
  • Parasitic: Toxoplasma, malaria.
  • Bacterial: Ureaplasma, chlamydia, brucella.
 

Maternal systemic diseases (Diabetes, thyroid disorders, hemoglobinopathies)

 

Endocrine Factors:

  • Luteal phase defect
  • Deficient progesterone
  • Thyroid abnormalities
  • Diabetes mellitus
 

Cervicouterine factors:

  • Fibroid
  • Intrauterine adhesions
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Mullerian anomalies
 

Environmental factors:

  • Smoking and alcohol consumption
  • Contraceptive agents like IUD

Parental Chromosomal Abnormalities.

  • Robertsonian translocations
  • Inversions
  • Aneuploidies
  • Other structural chromosomal abnormalities
 

Anatomical Factors:

  • Uterine Leiomyomas
  • Asherman Syndrome
  • Uterine Polyps
  • Mullerian Defects, most commonly septate uterus
 

Immunological Factors:

  • SLE
  • APLA
 

Endocrine Factors:

  • Overt Hypothyroidism and Iodine Deficiency
  • Subclinical Hypothyroidism with Anti-Thyroid Antibodies

questions.explanation:
Neurotransmitters

Source

Description

Acetylcholine (ACh)

Nucleus basalis of Meynert
  • Associated with Muscle contraction, Memory and REM sleep
  • NT* for Sweat glands

Norepinephrine (NE)

Locus ceruleus

Regulates wakefulness and alertness.

Dopamine

Substantia nigra
  • Destruction causes Parkinson’s disease.
  • NT* of reward and addiction.

Serotonin

Raphe nuclei
  • Regulation of mood, sleep, and appetite.
  • The highest concentration is in Platelets, enterochromaffin cells, and myenteric plexus.

questions.text: 2-5% of autopsies cannot determine the cause of death even after extensive lab investigations. What are such autopsies called?
questions.explanation:
Obscure autopsy (Option A ruled out)

Negative autopsy (Option B)
  • The cause of death may not be clear at the time of dissection but can often be determined after detailed clinical, and laboratory investigations, and interviews
  • Examples: Epilepsy, reflex vagal inhibition, uremia, and anesthetic overdose
  • The cause of death remains unknown even after extensive laboratory investigations
  • Occurs in 2-5% of all postmortem cases

questions.text: Which of the following contraceptive agents are used as the first-line agents in heavy menstrual bleeding?
Which of the following is incorrect about this scan?

options.label: A
options.text: Fibrous cortical defects show hot spot

options.label: B
options.text: Tracer in the bladder is physiological

options.label: C
options.text: In cellulitis tracer does not show prolonged retention in delayed phase

questions.correct_answer: A. Fibrous cortical defects show hot spot
questions.explanation:
Definition

Nuclear medicine study using technetium-99m (Tc-99m-MDP)

Absorption

~50% of injected dose absorbed by bones (2-6 hours post-injection)

Phases of Study

1. Immediate phase

2. Blood pool phase

3. Delayed phase

4. Optional delayed phase

Indications
  • Detection and follow-up of skeletal metastases
  • Radiographically occult fractures (e.g., stress fractures)
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Complex regional pain syndrome
  • Evaluation of hip joint prosthesis for infection or loosening
  • Paget disease

Patient Preparation
  • Optimal hydration
  • Remove metal objects
  • Void before study

Conditions Affecting Uptake
  • Increased uptake in kidneys/liver in conditions like thalassemia and hemochromatosis
  • Poor image quality with reduced renal function

Tracer Dose
  • 740 - 925 Mbq (20 - 25 mCi) administered intravenously in adults

Renal Uptake
  • Useful for detecting renal abnormalities; faint/absent uptake commonly due to renal insufficiency

Results

Normal: If the radiotracer is present evenly throughout all the bones.

Abnormal:

  • Will show hot spots or cold spots as compared to surrounding bone.
  • Hot spots are areas where there is an increased collection of radioactive material.
  • Cold spots are areas that have taken up less of the radioactive material.

Hot Spots

Areas of new bone formation; are seen in:

  • Fractures
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Osteoblastic bone metastasis

Cold Spots

Seen in:

  • Multiple myeloma (normal alkaline phosphatase)
  • Fibrous cortical defects (VS fibrous dysplasia shows hot spots)

Physiological Presence
  • Tracer present in the bladder due to renal excretion (Option B)

Criteria

Osteomyelitis

Cellulitis

Delayed Phase Imaging

Tracer retained in the bone (hot spot)

The tracer does not show prolonged retention in the bone (Option C)

Blood Pool Imaging

Increased uptake can occur

Increased uptake can also occur

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered overcrowding?

options.label: B

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Persons Per Room

Floor Space (1 sq.m. = 10 sq.ft.)
  • 1 room - 2 persons
  • 2 rooms - 3 persons
  • 3 rooms - 5 persons (option A)
  • 4 rooms - 7 persons
  • 5 or more rooms - 10 persons (2 per each room)
  • Not recommended: <50 sq.ft.
  • ½ person : 50-70 sq. ft. (option D)
  • 1 person: 70-90 sq. ft. (option B)
  • 1 ½ persons: 90-100 sq. ft.
  • 2 persons : >110 sq. ft.

questions.text: Match the following 1. Aliskiren a) Central sympatholytic 2. Lisinopril b) Acts on JG cells of the kidney to reduce renin release 3. Losartan c) Direct renin inhibitor 4. Clonidine d) Prevents formation of Angiotensin 2 5. Beta-blockers e) Block Angiotensin 1 receptor
questions.explanation:
Name of drug

Class

Mechanism of action

Aliskiren

Direct renin inhibitor

Blocks the formation of angiotensin 1, which decreases BP.

Lisinopril

ACE inhibitor

Blocks the conversion of angiotensin 1 to angiotensin 2

Losartan

ARB

Blocks angiotensin 1 receptor

Clonidine

Central sympatholytic

It acts on alpha 2A receptors, decreasing sympathetic discharge from the brain and reducing renin secretion.

Metoprolol, Atenolol

Beta-blockers

Act on JG cells of the kidney to reduce renin release.

questions.text: Before performing radial artery cannulation on a 7-year-old child for continuous blood pressure monitoring during major surgery, the anesthesiologist compresses both the radial and ulnar arteries, asks the child to make a fist, then releases the ulnar artery while keeping the radial artery compressed. What is the primary purpose of this maneuver?

options.label: A
options.text: To assess the elasticity of the arterial walls

options.label: B

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from a tropical region presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a soft, fleshy nasal mass. Histopathological examination reveals thick-walled sporangia filled with endospores and hyperplastic tissue without eosinophilic infiltration. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It affects the mucosal membrane of the nose only.

options.label: B
options.text: The recommended course of primary treatment is Dapsone

options.label: C
options.text: The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro

options.label: D
options.text: It is not associated with contaminated water exposure

questions.correct_answer: C. The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Causative Agent
  • Rhinosporidium seeberi - eukaryotic pathogen exhibiting features of fungi and protozoa; cannot be cultured in vitro (Option C)

Pathogenesis
  • Occurs via endospores infecting traumatized mucosal surfaces, leading to hyperplastic growths and rhinosporidial polyps

Histopathology
  • Presence of thick-walled sporangia (50-1000 μm) filled with endospores (5-10 μm)
  • Surrounding tissue shows hyperplasia and infiltration by inflammatory cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells)
  • The lack of eosinophilic infiltration distinguishes it from similar infections.

Staining Techniques
  • H&E: Identifies sporangia and inflammatory response
  • PAS: Stains endospores positively
  • GMS: Visualizes fungal elements

Treatment Option

Details

Surgical Intervention

Wide surgical excision of lesions.

Cauterization of base is recommended to minimize recurrence.

Adjunctive Therapy

Postoperative Dapsone is used to prevent recurrence, though efficacy is controversial due to resistance. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 50 y/o man undergoes a total hip replacement. Postoperatively, he develops difficulty walking and reports numbness along the posterior thigh, lateral leg, and sole of the foot. O/E, he has weakness in extending the hip and flexing the knee. The injured nerve originates from which of the following spinal roots?
questions.explanation:
Sciatic Nerve

Origin and Course
  • The thickest nerve in the body.
  • Arises from the ventral rami of L4–S3 spinal nerves. (Option A, C & D ruled out)
  • Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis and descends between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity along the back of the thigh.
  • Divides into the tibial and common peroneal nerves above the popliteal fossa.

Distribution

Motor:

  • Undivided Trunk: Supplies all muscles of the back of the thigh (hip extension, knee flexion).
  • Tibial Nerve: Innervates leg muscles (flexion) and foot muscles (plantar flexion).
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies leg muscles (dorsiflexion).

Sensory:

  • Tibial Nerve: Supplies skin on the back of the calf, heel, lateral border of the foot, and sole.
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies skin on the anterolateral and lateral surfaces of the leg and dorsum of the foot (except for the deep peroneal nerve area).

Clinical correlation

Injury of the sciatic nerve:

  • Causes: Penetrating wounds, posterior hip dislocation, pelvic fractures, total hip replacement, misplaced injections in the gluteal region.
  • Clinical Features:
  • Inability to extend the thigh and flex the knee (hamstring paralysis).
  • Loss of all movements below the knee (foot drop) leading to flail foot and high-stepping gait.
  • Loss of sensation on the back of the thigh, entire leg, and foot (except for the saphenous nerve area).

Sciatica:

  • Shooting pain along the sciatic nerve distribution (buttock, posterior thigh, lateral leg, dorsum of the foot).
  • Compression/irritation of L4–S3 spinal nerve roots due to herniated lumbar discs.

Neuropathy:

  • Entrapment in the piriformis muscle can lead to piriformis syndrome.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with weakness in the upper limb following a fall on his shoulder. Physical examination reveals impaired movement in the extensor muscles of the arm. Injury to which part of the brachial plexus is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Trunk

Formation

Divisions

Upper Trunk

Union of C5 and C6 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles

Middle Trunk


 

Continuation of C7

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option B ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles (Option C)

Lower Trunk

Union of C8 and T1 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Passing over first rib

Posterior: Extensor muscles

questions.text: A 26 y/o male from a rural area in India presents to the clinic with complaints of anxiety, fatigue, and weakness. He is preoccupied with the belief that he is losing semen during urination and nocturnal emissions. He also describes his semen as "milk-like." He is concerned that this will lead to physical weakness and impotence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Dhat syndrome

Koro syndrome
  • Definition: A psychiatric condition marked by fear of semen loss through ejaculation, nocturnal emission, or other means.
  • Cultural Context: Leading culture-bound syndrome in the Indian subcontinent, tied to Ayurvedic beliefs that semen is vital for health.
  • Demographics: Affects young, unmarried males from lower socioeconomic and rural backgrounds.
  • Age: The average onset is around 26 years.
  • This can lead to depression and sexual dysfunction
  • Clinical Presentation
    • Symptoms: Anxiety, fatigue, weakness, and impotence from the fear of semen loss.
    • Beliefs: Semen loss through nocturnal emissions, urination, defecation, or arousal.
    • Somatic Complaints: Physical symptoms tied to weakness, infertility, and fear of death.
    • Semen Description: Often described as "milk-like" or "pus-like."
  • Treatment
    • Psychiatric Care: Treated similarly to depression, with psychotherapy (sex education to dispel the myths) and antidepressants.
  • Diagnosis
    • ICD-10: Concern over semen loss (seen as whitish discharge in urine) with associated anxiety and physical symptoms.

Female Dhat syndrome, presenting with nonpathological vaginal discharge ("safedpaani") seen as a vital fluid, is triggered by warm foods, stress, and dietary imbalances, causing somatic symptoms and linked to Ayurvedic beliefs about bodily balance.
  • Definition: A psychiatric disorder characterized by an intense fear of genital retraction into the body, believed to result in death (in males, the penis; in females, the vulva or breasts).
  • Epidemiology:
    • Epidemic Koro: Common in parts of East and Southeast Asia (e.g., China, India, Malaysia), linked to cultural beliefs and myths.
    • Sporadic Koro: Occurs globally, unrelated to culture, often secondary to psychiatric disorders (e.g., schizophrenia, depression) or substance use.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Overwhelming anxiety with belief of genital retraction and impending death.
    • Symptoms: Panic attacks, physical attempts to prevent retraction, measuring genitals, insomnia, and fear of death
  • Treatment:
    • Psychotherapy: Sex education and counselling to dispel myths.
    • Medications: Anxiolytics, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and sedatives (based on psychiatric comorbidities).

questions.text: All the factors inhibit gastric emptying except?

options.label: B
options.text: A large volume of solid meals

questions.explanation:
Factor

Mechanism

Vagal stimulation

Stimulates antral contraction, promoting gastric emptying

Liquid meal

Faster gastric emptying due to lower viscosity and faster transit through the stomach

Motilin

Stimulates antral contraction and gastric emptying, especially during the interdigestive state

Factor

Mechanism

Acid in the duodenum

Releases secretin, inhibiting antral contraction and stimulating pyloric sphincter contraction

Products of fat digestion

Releases CCK and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Hypertonic solutions in the duodenum

Releases hormones inhibiting gastric emptying

Products of protein digestion

Releases gastrin, CCK, and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Large meal volume (solids)

Prolongs gastric emptying time

Stretching of duodenum

Initiates enterogastric reflex, inhibiting gastric emptying

Sympathetic stimulation

Decreased gastric motility (by norepinephrine) and increased pyloric sphincter tone.

Hormones (CCK, GIP, secretin)

-

Feature

Schwannomas (esp. vestibular)

Multiple CALMs, no neurofibromas, Lisch nodules

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines acts on B cells to stimulate class switching to IgE and promotes the development of additional Th2 cells in type I hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.explanation:
Interleukins

Role

IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells

IL-5 (Option B)

Development and activation of eosinophils→ Recruited to the site of allergen exposure→ Release inflammatory mediators and enzymes→ Tissue damage and inflammation

IL-13 (Option C)
  • Amplifies IgE production
  • Acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion

IL-10 (Option D)
  • Anti-inflammatory cytokine
  • Inhibits cytokine production by Th1 cells and macrophages.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with palpable purpura on the lower extremities, arthralgia, and abdominal pain. Laboratory tests show elevated serum IgA levels and red blood cell casts in urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (IgA vasculitis)

It is a systemic vasculitis characterised by inflammation of small blood vessels, primarily affecting children, but can also occur in adults.

Etiology

Often follows upper respiratory tract infections

Pathology

Immune complex deposition of IgA in small blood vessels leads to inflammation

Clinical features

  • Inflammation of small blood vessels, primarily affecting children, but can also occur in adults.
  • Associated with elevated serum IgA levels
  • Skin: Palpable purpura, most prominently on the lower limbs and buttocks.
  • Musculoskeletal: Arthralgia or arthritis, often transient and non-deforming.
  • Gastrointestinal: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes gastrointestinal bleeding, Intussusception is a severe but rare complication.
  • Renal: Hematuria, proteinuria, and red blood cell casts in urine.
  • Can progress to IgA nephropathy in severe cases.

Management

  • Supportive care: Hydration, rest, and pain management with NSAIDs for arthralgia.
  • Glucocorticoids: For severe abdominal pain, renal involvement, or systemic symptoms.
  • Intussusception: Surgical intervention if required.
  • Nephritis: Immunosuppressants (e.g., cyclophosphamide) in severe cases.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male following RTA presented with a deformity of the lower limb. The clinician prescribed him a splint as shown below. What is the likely site of injury in this patient based on the markings in this X-ray?
questions.explanation:
Anatomy:
  • The terminal branch of the sciatic nerve arises from the popliteal fossa.
  • Root value: L4,L5,S1 & S2.
  • Hooks around the neck of the fibula.
  • Terminates by dividing into Superficial peroneal nerve & Deep peroneal nerve

Muscles supplied:
  • Superficial peroneal nerve: Peroneus longus & brevis (foot eversion)
  • Deep peroneal nerve: Peroneus tertius, Tibialis anterior, Extensor digitorum, Extensor hallucis longus.

Cutaneous supply of foot:

Common peroneal nerve injury:

Causes
  • Most common: Neck of fibula fracture (Option D)
  • Posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Fracture lateral tibial condyle

Clinical features
  • Foot drop (inability to evert)
  • High stepping gait

Treatment
  • Conservative (mainstay): Foot drop splint

  • Surgical (tendon transfer) - only done >12 months of no recovery:
    • Barr’s technique
    • Ober’s technique

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has a history of recurrent peptic ulcers and severe abdominal pain. Despite the use of proton pump inhibitors, his symptoms persist. Endoscopic examination reveals small nodules in the medial wall of the duodenum. His family history is significant for multiple endocrine neoplasia type I. Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The tumors are most commonly found in the tail of the pancreas.

options.label: B
options.text: The condition is curable with surgical removal of the primary tumor.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient's gastrinoma is likely located within the gastrinoma triangle.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of proton pump inhibitors has made diagnosis of this condition easier

questions.correct_answer: C. The patient's gastrinoma is likely located within the gastrinoma triangle.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Tumor Location

Duodenal loop, Pancreas (head) (Option A ruled out)

Causes

Persistent peptic ulceration

Historical Recognition

Severe peptic ulcers unresponsive to surgery pre-PPI era. The use of proton pump inhibitors has made the condition controllable but harder to recognize. (Option D ruled out)

Types

Sporadic, MEN type I (with parathyroid adenoma)

Common Locations

Gastrinoma Triangle (cystic duct/common bile duct, duodenum, pancreas) (Option C)

Detection

Small nodules in duodenal wall, endoscopic and surgical inspection needed

Course

Indolent for some malignant gastrinomas

Treatment

Palliative liver resection, liver transplantation, surgical removal for palliation in MEN type I as they are incurable. (Option B ruled out)

Prognosis

Worse for tumors outside gastrinoma triangle

questions.text: Which of the following components is not evaluated in the Bloom-Richardson grading system?
questions.explanation:
Features

Score

Tubule Formation:

Percentage of the tumor that forms normal duct structures
  • Score 1: >75% of tumor area forms tubules
  • Score 2: 10-75% of tumor area forms tubules
  • Score 3: <10% of tumor area forms tubules

Nuclear Pleomorphism:

Variation in size and shape of the tumor cell nuclei
  • Score 1: Small, uniform nuclei
  • Score 2: Moderate increase in size and variability
  • Score 3: Marked variation in size and shape, large and bizarre nuclei

Mitotic Count:

Number of mitoses per 10 high-power fields
  • Score 1: 0-9 mitoses per 10 high-power fields
  • Score 2: 10-19 mitoses per 10 high-power fields
  • Score 3: 20 or more mitoses per 10 high-power fields

Grades

Score

Grade 1 : Well-differentiated

3-5

Grade 2 : Moderately differentiated

6-7

Grade 3 : Poorly differentiated

8-9

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain and fever. According to the Tokyo Guidelines, which combination of findings would confirm a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis?

options.label: A
options.text: RUQ tenderness, elevated C-reactive protein, gallbladder wall thickening on USG.

options.label: B
options.text: Murphy's sign, fever, normal gallbladder wall on USG.

options.label: C
options.text: Palpable RUQ mass, normal white blood cell count, pericholecystic fluid on USG.

options.label: D
options.text: RUQ pain, elevated C-reactive protein, no imaging finding

questions.correct_answer: A. RUQ tenderness, elevated C-reactive protein, gallbladder wall thickening on USG.
questions.explanation:
Tokyo Guidelines for Acute Cholecystitis (2013/2018)

A) Local Signs of Inflammation:
  • Murphy's sign
  • Right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain/ tenderness, or a palpable mass.

B) Systemic Signs of Inflammation:
  • Fever
  • Elevated CRP
  • Elevated WBC

C) Imaging Findings:
  • Gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm)
  • Pericholecystic fluid,
  • Ultrasonographic Murphy's sign.

Analyze the following statements regarding the structural model of mind and choose the correct set of true statements from these 1) Ego lies in all three- conscious, preconscious & unconscious parts of the mind 2) Instinctual drives are a part of Id. 3) The superego is mostly present in the conscious part of the mind.
questions.explanation:
Id:
  • Instinctive drives
  • Based on the pleasure principle (immediate gratification)
  • Operates under primary processes
  • Lies in the unconscious mind

Ego:
  • The executive organ of the mind
  • Maintains balance between Id and Superego
  • Works on the reality principle
  • Lies in all three - conscious, preconscious and unconscious parts of the mind

Superego:
  • Moral compass insisting on socially acceptable behavior
  • Develops after 5 years (after resolution of oedipal complex)
  • Predominantly present in the unconscious part of the mind

Which imaging technique is most suitable for visualizing the compression of the duodenum by the SMA and accurately measuring the aortomesenteric angle?

A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, heart rate is 110 bpm, and has cold, clammy skin and elevated JVP. ECG shows ST-segment elevations in lead II, III and aVF. The patient is also oliguric. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms and signs?
questions.explanation:
Types of shock

Pathophysiology

Causes

Cardiac output

Cardiogenic

(Option A)

Inadequate pumping of the heart due to myocardial function.
  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Heart failure
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  

↓

Hypovolemic

Decreased amount of fluid in the vascular system
  • Acute hemorrhage
  • Burn
  • Metabolic: adrenal insufficiency (Option C ruled out), diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Severe diarrhea or vomiting.

 

↓

Distributive

Sudden increase in the vascular compartment capacity due to acute marked vasodilation
  • Neurogenic shock
  • Anaphylactic shock
  • Septic shock (Option B ruled out)

 

↓

Obstructive

Obstruction to the ejection of blood from the ventricle
  • Cardiac tamponade (Option D ruled out)
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Cardiac tumor
  • Tension pneumothorax

 

↓

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly matches with the medications? 1. Metoprolol A. Contraindicated with Non-DHP calcium channel blockers. 2. Ivabradine B. Increase risk of oral ulcers. 3. Trimetazidine C. Abrupt discontinuation can exacerbate angina. 4. Enoxaparin D. Increase risk of Parkinson’s disease. 5. Nicorandil E. Contraindicated in renal insufficiency.
questions.explanation:
Medication

Adverse effects

1. Beta-blockers (e.g metorprolol)
  • Abrupt discontinuation can exacerbate angina.
  • Bradycardia, AV block
  • Bronchospasm
  • Peripheral vasoconstriction
  • Worsening of acute heart failure.
  • Worsening of psoriasis.

2. Ivabradine
  • Contraindicated with diltiazem or verapamil.
  • Bradycardia, heart block
  • QT prolongation, atrial fibrillation
  • Enhanced lightness in restricted areas of the visual field.

3. Trimetazidine
  • Increase incidence of Parkinson’s disease.
  • Agranulocytosis

4.Low-molecular-weight heparin (e.g., enoxaparin, dalteparin)
  • Accumulation in renal insufficiency.
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
  • Raised liver enzymes.

5. Nicorandil
  • Hypotension
  • Headache
  • Buccal and GI ulcers
  • Contraindicated with PDE5 inhibitor.

Variants of Meniere’s disease

Variant

Description

Pathophysiology

Cochlear Hydrops

Symptoms primarily involve the cochlea: fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness, but no vertigo.

Increased fluid pressure confined to the cochlea, often due to a blockage at the ductus reuniens.

Vestibular Hydrops

Presents with episodic vertigo while cochlear function remains normal (no hearing loss, tinnitus, or fullness).

Fluid pressure affects the vestibular structures, particularly the saccule and utricle, sparing cochlear function.

Tumarkin’s Otolithic Crisis

Sudden"drop attacks" without loss of consciousness and no vertigo or hearing loss

Deformation of otolith membrane of the utricle or saccule due to change in endolymphatic pressure

Lermoyez Syndrome

Symptoms of Meniere’s are seen in reverse order—progressive hearing loss followed by vertigo.

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents with a painless erection following a penile trauma. Doppler ultrasound confirms the presence of blood flow and blood gas analysis shows arterial blood characteristics. What is the most likely type of priapism?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Ischemic Priapism  (Option A)

Nonischemic Priapism

Alternative Names

Low-flow, Anoxic, Veno-occlusive.

High-flow, Arterial.

Commonality

More common

Less common

Onset

Sudden, often painful.

Gradual, less painful.

Etiology

Associated with sickle cell disease, medications (anticoagulants, antihypertensives, antidepressants, PDE5 inhibitors, intracavernous injections, alpha-blockers, methylphenidate, atomoxetine, cocaine), blood disorders (leukemia, thalassemia, multiple myeloma, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura).

Often due to trauma (Perineal, pelvic, or penile trauma) or congenital arterial malformations.

Blood Flow

Decreased or absent (leading to hypoxia and acidosis)

Increased (blood is well-oxygenated)

Cavernosal Blood Gas Analysis

Dark blood, pH <7.25, PO2 <30 mmHg, PCO2 >60 mmHg.

Bright red blood, normal pH, normal PO2 and PCO2.

Doppler Ultrasonography

Minimal or no blood flow in the corpora cavernosa

Normal to increased blood flow

Urgency

Medical emergency

Not an emergency, often resolves spontaneously.

Complications

Risk of tissue damage, fibrosis and long-term erectile dysfunction.

Rarely causes permanent damage.

Treatment
  • Intracavernosal sympathomimetic drugs (e.g., phenylephrine)
  • Aspiration and irrigation.
  • Surgical shunt or penile prosthesis if refractory.
  • Observation
  • Arteriography and embolization if intervention is desired.

Prognosis

Poor if untreated within 24-48 hours, leading to irreversible erectile dysfunction.

Good, often resolves without long-term sequelae.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with a history of chronic migraines and increased intracranial pressure due to a recent stroke is scheduled for a minor procedure requiring anesthesia. Which anesthetic agent should be avoided in this patient?
questions.explanation:
System

Effects

CNS
  • It is associated with increased cerebral oxygen consumption, blood flow, and intracranial pressure.
  • It causes functional disorganization by selectively depressing neuronal activity in the cortex and thalamus while stimulating the limbic system, leading to disrupted pain perception and emotional processing.
  • Emergence reactions, including vivid dreams, hallucinations, and illusion, occurs due to depression of auditory and visual relay nuclei,
  • It provides analgesia, amnesia, and unconsciousness, making it a "complete" anesthetic.

CVS
  • Increases arterial blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output, particularly after rapid bolus injections.
  • Stimulates the sympathetic nervous system and inhibits norepinephrine reuptake, increasing pulmonary artery pressure and myocardial workload.
  • Direct myocardial depression can occur with sympathetic blockade or catecholamine depletion.

Respiratory
  • Racemic ketamine is a strong bronchodilator, useful in asthmatic patients.
  • Upper airway reflexes remain intact.
  • Excessive salivation can be managed with anticholinergics (e.g., glycopyrrolate).

Muscle
  • It increases muscle tone

questions.text: Which of the following changes does not occur in fetal circulation following birth?

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in mass and volume of the left ventricle

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in mass and volume of the right ventricle

questions.correct_answer: D. Increase in mass and volume of the right ventricle
questions.explanation:
Parameter/Structure

Change

Cause

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance (PVR)

Decreases

(Option A ruled out)

Mechanical expansion of the lungs and increased arterial PO2 lead to a rapid decrease in PVR.

Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR)

Increases

The removal of the low-resistance placental circulation results in an increase in SVR.

Ductus Arteriosus Shunt

Reverses and eventually closes.
  • As PVR becomes lower than SVR, the shunt through the ductus arteriosus reverses from right-to-left to left-to-right.
  • High arterial PO2 leads to the constriction and eventual closure of the ductus arteriosus, which later becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

Foramen Ovale

Closes

Increased pulmonary blood flow to the left atrium raises left atrial volume and pressure, leading to the functional closure of the foramen ovale.

Ductus Venosus

Closes

(Option C ruled out)

The removal of the placenta from circulation results in the closure of the ductus venosus.

Left ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Increases

(Option B ruled out)

The left ventricle's wall thickness and mass increase as it adapts to the high-resistance systemic circulation.

Right ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Decreases

(Option D)

The right ventricle's wall thickness and mass decrease as it adapts to the low-resistance pulmonary circulation.

Left Ventricular Output

Increases

The left ventricle now must deliver the entire systemic cardiac output, which is almost a 200% increase compared to fetal conditions.

Right Ventricular Output

Increases

Opening of pulmonary vasculature results in increased right ventricular output.

Shunt

Functional Closure

Anatomical closure

Remnant

Ductus Arteriosus

10-15 hrs after birth

2 -3 weeks after birth

Ligamentum arteriosum

Foramen ovale

3rd month

1 year after birth

Fossa ovalis

Ductus venosus

Immediately after birth

3-7 days after birth

Ligamentum venosum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with persistent nasal crusting and foul odour, unresponsive to medical treatment. Which procedure narrows the nasal cavity to reduce crusting?

options.label: B
options.text: Use of 25% glucose in glycerine nasal application

options.label: C
options.text: Nasal irrigation with an alkaline solution

questions.explanation:
Treatment

Details

Nasal Irrigation and Crust Removal
  • Use warm normal saline or an alkaline solution for nasal irrigation.
  • Irrigate multiple times daily initially, reducing to once every 2-3 days as symptoms improve.
  • For stubborn crusts, use glucose-glycerin solution before removal with forceps or suction.

Topical Applications

Apply 25% glucose in glycerine to inhibit proteolytic bacteria growth, reducing foul smell.

Antibiotics
  • Systemic antibiotics (e.g., fluoroquinolones with metronidazole) for 7-10 days.
  • Long-term use is not recommended.

Other Therapies
  • Mucolytics: Potassium iodide solutions to liquefy secretions.
  • Experimental: Oestradiol nasal sprays and submucosal placental extract injections have been explored.

Dietary Recommendations

A balanced diet rich in vitamins A, D, folic acid, iron, and protein to support overall health and mucosal recovery.

Procedure

Details

Young's Operation and Modifications
  • Complete closure of both nostrils in the nasal vestibule.
  • Reopen nostrils after approximately 6 months to encourage mucosal regeneration and reduce crusting.
  • Modified versions partially close nostrils to reduce discomfort while aiming for similar benefits.

Techniques to narrow excessively wide nasal chambers
  • Autologous grafts (fat, cartilage, bone) placed under the mucoperiosteum of nasal floor/lateral walls or mucoperichondrium of septum.
  • Allografts (Alloderm, Cymetra) can be used.
  • The Lautenschlaeger technique involves medial displacement of the lateral nasal wall to narrow nasal cavities which can help reduce crusting by improving airflow and humidifying the nasal passages. (Option D)

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents with severe breathlessness, palpitations, and swelling in her legs and face. She primarily eats white rice and lacks fruits and vegetables in her diet. On examination and investigations she has distended neck veins, peripheral edema, and elevated lactate and pyruvate levels. Thiamine deficiency is suspected. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which enzyme activity should be tested to confirm it?

options.label: B
options.text: Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD); branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase

questions.explanation:
Condition Biochemical Role of Thiamine Deficiency Manifestations
Dry Beriberi (Option A ruled out) Essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function Peripheral neuritis, sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, paralysis due to CNS involvement.
Wet Beriberi Thiamine is required for pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex; deficiency leads to lactic acidosis, causing vasodilation and cardiovascular symptoms Edema, palpitations, breathlessness, heart failure
Maple Syrup Urine Disease (Option B ruled out) Cofactor for decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids Accumulation of branched-chain keto acids, causing convulsions, mental retardation, vomiting, acidosis, coma, and death
Lactic Acidosis (Option D ruled out) Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, which converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA Impaired pyruvate metabolism, leading to increased lactate and pyruvate, causing lactic acidosis

questions.text: Which of the following acts cannot be considered as rape?

options.label: A
options.text: Inserting an article into the urethra

options.label: B
options.text: Manipulating any part of a woman’s body to cause penetration

questions.explanation:
BNS

BNS 63 (Old: Section 375 IPC)

Definition

Unlawful sexual intercourse by a man with a woman through force or under certain conditions

Acts considered

  • Penetrates his penis into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus
  • Inserts any object or body part (not his penis) or applies his mouth to the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus (Option A ruled out) (Option D ruled out)
  • Manipulates any part of the woman's body to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, or anus (Option B ruled out)

Circumstances

  • Against her will
  • Without her consent
  • With her consent obtained through fear of death or hurt
  • With her consent, when she believes he is her husband due to impersonation
  • When she cannot understand the nature of consent due to unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or being drugged
  • Statutory rape: With or without her consent, if she is under 18 years of age
  • When she is unable to communicate consent

Exception

  • Medical interventions or procedures
  • Sexual intercourse by a man with his wife if she is not under 18 years of age (Option C)

questions.text: A 28 year old woman, G2 P1 L1 at 38 weeks gestation is seen in early labor. She has a history of cesarean section done 3 years ago for breech presentation. The obstetrician decides on a cesarean section. Which of the following is NOT an indication for a cesarean section in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Maternal Indications for Cesarean Delivery
  • Prior Cesarean Delivery: most common
  • Abnormal Placentation (Option A): Placenta previa and placenta accreta
  • Prior Classical Hysterotomy
  • Prior Uterine Incision Extension
  • Uterine Incision Dehiscence (Option B)
  • Prior Full-Thickness Myomectomy
  • Genital Tract Obstructive Mass
  • Invasive Cervical Cancer
  • Prior Trachelectomy
  • Permanent Cerclage
  • Prior Pelvic Reconstructive Surgery
  • Prior Significant Perineal Trauma
  • Pelvic Deformity
  • HSV or HIV Infection
  • Cardiac or Pulmonary Disease.
  • Cerebral Aneurysm or Arteriovenous Malformation: Increase the risk of a stroke
  • Pathology Requiring Concurrent Intraabdominal Surgery
  • Perimortem Cesarean Delivery

Selection criteria for TOLAC

Contraindications for TOLAC

One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar

Previous classical or inverted T shaped uterine incision

Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section

Previous more than two lower segment cesarean section

Pelvis adequate for fetus

Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD

Continued labor monitoring possible

Presence of other complications in pregnancy: obstetric ( malpresentation , pre-eclampsia , placenta previa) or medical

Availability of resources (anesthesia , blood transfusion) for emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes of decision

Resources limited for emergency cesarean delivery or patient refusal for TOLAC

Informed consent of the women

History of prior uterine rupture

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with diabetes arrives at the emergency department with sudden right-sided weakness and trouble speaking. His examination shows left-sided ptosis, the left eye in a "down and out" position, and right-sided paralysis of the lower face. What is the most likely diagnosis?
